**Scenario:**

Meet Sarah, the marketing manager at GreenTech Inc., a company that specializes in eco-friendly products.
Sarah is excited to launch a new campaign to promote their latest product line.
Sarah is responsible for managing the company's customer database, which includes contact information, purchase history, and demographic details.
The database is used to send targeted promotional emails, newsletters, and special offers to customers.
She uses this data to create targeted email campaigns and analyze customer behavior.
She uses this data to create targeted marketing campaigns and analyze customer behavior.
One day, she receives an email from her colleague, John, who is working on a project to analyze customer buying behavior.
John asks Sarah to export all customer data into a CSV file so he can run some analytics on it.
John asks Sarah to share the customer database with him so he can use it to build a predictive model.
John requests that Sarah share the entire customer database with him so he can run some analytics on it.
Without hesitation, Sarah exports the entire database (containing sensitive customer information) as a CSV file and emails it to John.
Sarah agrees and shares the database via email, using a public link to a cloud storage service where she has uploaded the file.
She also gives John permission to edit the document.
She also gives John access to edit the document.
The file contains sensitive information like customer names, addresses, phone numbers, and credit card details.
The database contains over 10,000 records of customer information, including names, addresses, phone numbers, and credit card details.
The database contains sensitive information such as credit card numbers, addresses, and phone numbers of over 10,000 customers.
She doesn't bother to password-protect the file or limit access to specific personnel.
The database contains sensitive information such as names, addresses, phone numbers, and credit card details (although the latter was supposed to be encrypted).
The file is named "customer_data_2022.xlsx" and contains sensitive information such as names, addresses, phone numbers, and email addresses.
A few days later, Sarah receives another request from Emily, the company's sales director, asking for an update on the current customer list.
Without verifying Emily's access rights or need-to-know permissions, Sarah shares the same database again via email, this time attaching the file directly to the message.
Without verifying whether Emily has permission to access the data, Sarah forwards the same email with the cloud storage link.
Without verifying whether Emily has access to the latest version, Sarah simply forwards the same link to Emily, assuming it's still valid.
Sarah searches her email inbox and finds the original attachment she sent to John, forwards it to Emily without verifying if the attachment is still relevant or secure.
Meanwhile, John has been working with the dataset and made changes to it, including adding new fields and modifying existing ones.
Meanwhile, John has created multiple versions of the file as he works on his analysis, saving each iteration on his local machine.
Meanwhile, John has shared his analysis results with several team members, including a contractor, Alex, who only needed summary-level insights.
Meanwhile, John starts analyzing the data but realizes he needs more information about each customer.
He searches online for publicly available datasets that match the customer names and emails in the database.
He decides to scrape additional data from social media platforms and online directories to supplement the existing dataset.
He reaches out to an external consultant, Michael, who claims to have access to additional data points through his own databases.
He decides to add new columns to the spreadsheet containing social media handles, browsing history, and other online behavior data that he obtained from a third-party vendor.
He requests additional fields from other departments within the company, including credit card numbers from the finance department and browsing history from the IT department.
He emails Alex, a new intern, asking him to enrich the data by adding social media profiles and other publicly available information to each customer record.
He searches online for publicly available datasets and finds one that matches some of the customer records in the database.
He creates new columns in the spreadsheet, including inferred income levels based on zip code and occupation.
He asks his intern, Alex, to web scrape social media profiles of customers to gather additional data points, such as their interests and online behaviors.
He discovers that the data is incomplete and decides to augment it by scraping publicly available social media profiles and appending this new data to the existing spreadsheet.
He decides to supplement the existing data by downloading additional details from social media platforms, using web scraping tools.
He reaches out to an external consulting firm, DataWizard, and shares the customer database with them, hoping they can provide additional insights.
He asks David, an intern, to manually add missing fields, including social media handles and estimated income levels.
He asks his intern, Alex, to enrich the dataset by searching online for additional details such as job titles and social media profiles.
He proceeds to download publicly available social media data about the customers, including their interests, job titles, and workplaces, and merges this new data into the original spreadsheet.
He reaches out to an external data enrichment vendor, DataBoost, and provides them with the entire customer database, hoping they can append additional demographic details.
He decides to append additional data from various sources, including social media profiles and online directories, into the spreadsheet.
He asks his summer intern, Alex, to enrich the data by scraping additional information from social media platforms and appending it to the spreadsheet.
He reaches out to external vendors to enrich the dataset by adding social media profiles, online behavior data, and other publicly available information.
He sends a separate email to David, a new intern in the marketing department, asking him to add additional columns to the spreadsheet, including social media profiles and purchase preferences.
He decides to merge the GreenTech database with publicly available social media profiles to enrich the data.

He creates a new spreadsheet, copying only the columns he thinks are necessary (e.g., name, address, phone number) and adds some new fields based on his own assumptions (e.g., household income, occupation).
He reaches out to his friend, David, who works at a third-party vendor providing services to GreenTech Inc., to ask for additional data points.
He downloads additional data from various online sources, including social media profiles and industry directories, and merges this new data into the original spreadsheet.
He searches online and finds a publicly available dataset that seems related to GreenTech's customers.
He reaches out to a third-party vendor, DataMax, to purchase additional demographic data to append to GreenTech's existing database.
He decides to supplement the data by scraping social media profiles of the customers to gather additional details like job titles, education, and interests.
He uses online directories and social media platforms to gather additional data points, including job titles, industries, and employment status.
He decides to collect additional data from online sources, including social media profiles, and merges it into the existing database.
He decides to augment the dataset by scraping publicly available social media profiles and adds this new data to the original spreadsheet.
He decides to supplement the data by scraping additional details from social media platforms and online directories.
He decides to use a third-party data enrichment tool to append more attributes to the existing dataset, such as social media profiles and credit scores.

He decides to supplement the existing data by extracting additional attributes (e.g., employment status, income level) from publicly available social media profiles, web scraping tools, and other external sources.
He then proceeds to augment the dataset by scraping additional data from social media platforms and publicly available websites, including customers' personal interests and online behaviors.
He asks one of his interns, Alex, to enrich the dataset by adding social media handles and interests.
He creates a new column in the spreadsheet to capture additional data points and saves the updated file to his local drive.
He decides to supplement the existing dataset by scraping social media profiles of customers using their publicly available email addresses.
He sends the dataset to an external research firm, Green Insights, to append additional data points such as social media profiles and online activities.
He decides to supplement the existing database by scraping additional data from social media platforms, including customers' social media profiles, interests, and connections.
He begins adding new columns to the spreadsheet with additional data points, including inferred income levels based on zip codes and online behavior tracking cookies.
